help.title: Application information
help.objective_description: RegressionLab is an application designed to perform experimental data fitting comfortably, accurately, and quickly. It handles experimental uncertainties and proper formatting, ideal for experimental physics, experimental sciences, engineering, and Computer Science. Especially useful for students who need to fit data without programming complexities, or as a validation tool for results.
help.advantage_1: ‚Ä¢ **Easy setup and use**: Place your data (Excel or CSV) in a folder, run the application, and get professional plots and properly formatted results ready to copy.
help.advantage_2: ‚Ä¢ **Fit to known functions**: Perform normal fits with predefined or custom functions quickly and directly.
help.advantage_3: ‚Ä¢ **Loop mode for incremental data**: Add data progressively to your file while validating everything works correctly, without reconfiguring each time.
help.advantage_4: ‚Ä¢ **Multiple datasets**: Test the same hypothesis on different data series (e.g., same experiment on different days) systematically.
help.advantage_5: ‚Ä¢ **Hypothesis exploration**: Try several or all available functions on the same data to find the best model.
help.advantage_6: ‚Ä¢ **Versatile and accessible**: Available as desktop application, web (Streamlit), and soon mobile version. No complex installation required.
help.advantage_7: ‚Ä¢ **Highly configurable**: Customize colors, plot styles, fonts, and more through understandable environment variables.
help.advantage_8: ‚Ä¢ **Extensible**: Add new fitting functions relatively easily to adapt the application to your needs.
help.advantage_9: ‚Ä¢ **Custom functions**: Coming soon, you'll be able to add custom functions directly from the interface with a button.
help.normal_fitting: ‚Ä¢ Normal fitting: Fits one equation to one dataset.
help.multiple_datasets: ‚Ä¢ Fit multiple datasets: Fits the same equation to multiple datasets.
help.checker_fitting: ‚Ä¢ Fit multiple functions: Tests different equations on the same dataset.
help.total_fitting: ‚Ä¢ Fit all functions: Applies all available equations to one dataset.
help.loop_mode: ‚Ä¢ Loop mode: Allows iterative reloading and refitting of data.
help.data_format_named: ‚Ä¢ **Named columns**: One column per magnitude, one per uncertainty (headers required).
help.data_format_u_prefix: ‚Ä¢ **Uncertainty columns**: Use 'u' + variable name (e.g. ux, uy).
help.data_format_non_negative: ‚Ä¢ **Non-negative uncertainties**: All uncertainty values must be ‚â• 0.
help.data_input: ‚Ä¢ Data files should be in the 'input/' folder
help.output_plots: ‚Ä¢ Plots are saved in the 'output/' folder
help.r_squared_desc: ‚Ä¢ **R¬≤ (coefficient of determination)**: Proportion of the variance in y explained by the model. Value between 0 and 1; the closer to 1, the better the fit.
help.r_squared_formula: Formula: R¬≤ = 1 ‚àí SS_res/SS_tot, with SS_res = Œ£(y‚àí≈∑)¬≤ and SS_tot = Œ£(y‚àí»≥)¬≤ (≈∑ = fitted value, »≥ = mean of y).
help.chi_squared_desc: ‚Ä¢ **œá¬≤ (chi-squared)**: Sum of squared residuals weighted by uncertainties. Lower values indicate a better fit when uncertainties are well estimated.
help.chi_squared_formula: Formula: œá¬≤ = Œ£ [(y‚àí≈∑)/u_y]¬≤, where u_y is the uncertainty of each y value.
help.reduced_chi_squared_desc: ‚Ä¢ **œá¬≤_red (reduced chi-squared)**: œá¬≤ divided by degrees of freedom. A value close to 1 suggests uncertainties are consistent with the fit.
help.dof_desc: ‚Ä¢ **ŒΩ (degrees of freedom)**: Number of data points minus number of fitted parameters. Quantifies the information remaining after the fit.
help.dof_formula: Formula: ŒΩ = n ‚àí p (n = number of points, p = number of parameters).
help.param_ci_95_desc: ‚Ä¢ **95% CI (95% confidence interval)**: For each parameter, the range within which the true value is expected with 95% confidence (t-distribution).
help.param_ci_95_formula: Calculation: [Œ∏ ‚àí t¬∑œÉ_Œ∏, Œ∏ + t¬∑œÉ_Œ∏], where Œ∏ is the parameter, œÉ_Œ∏ its uncertainty, and t the 97.5% percentile of the t-distribution with ŒΩ degrees of freedom.
